data.title: The Other, Less-Known ‘Rankin/Bass’ Stop-Motion Santa Claus Movie

data.text:
Beginning with Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer in 1964, Rankin/Bass created a name for themselves as creators of animated specials, many of which have gone on to become traditional viewing at Christmastime (and one a cult Halloween title). Their films were made in both traditional hand-drawn cell animation and stop-motion animation, but it is their stop-motion style that would become the hallmark of the company. One of their better-known offerings is Santa Claus is Comin’ to Town, which first aired in 1970, offering an origin story for the man in red, starring the voice talents of Fred Astaire and Mickey Rooney. But in 1985, near the tail end of the studio’s output, Rankin/Bass produced another take on the origins of Santa Claus, one which has not been given as much attention as it deserves: The Life and Adventures of Santa Claus.

This production was based on the 1902 novel of the same name by American author L. Frank Baum, best known for penning The Wonderful Wizard of Oz. While Baum’s Oz books aimed to create “modern fairytales” and told their stories in a fairly straightforward and matter-of-fact way, The Life and Adventures of Santa Claus strikes a very different tone, having a more folkloric and mythological flavour.
